author: Western Morning News
title: MP's push Chancellor George Osborne for 5% tobacco tax hike
text:
Comments (0) 
MPs are urging Chancellor George Osborne to raise tax on tobacco to help persuade smokers to quit. 
The All-Party Parliamentary Group on Smoking and Health wants the annual rate on tobacco to be increased from 2% above inflation to 5%. 
The move would raise an extra £100 million a year that could be spent on helping people stop smoking, the group said, and also recommended that spending on anti-smoking efforts should be increased from £200m to £300m, paid for by the tax hike. 
The group’s report is being submitted to the Treasury’s Comprehensive Spending Review, the BBC said. 
Group chairman Bob Blackman, the Conservative MP for Harrow East, said: “Smokers don’t just die early, they suffer many years of disease and disability before they do, putting pressure not just on the NHS, but additional disability and social care costs and reduced income tax. 
“Every pound invested over the next five years could deliver £11 to the public purse.” 
But representatives of tobacco manufacturers described the proposals as economically “illiterate” and “counter-productive”. 
Giles Roca, director general of the Tobacco Manufacturers’ Association, said: “Every time taxation is increased on tobacco it loses the Treasury millions that could have been spent on public services. 
“That’s because tax on tobacco has increased by over 40% over the last five years, making UK tobacco the most expensive in Europe. Smokers are then increasingly switching to cheaper and often illegal products, which loses the Treasury some £2.6 billion each year.” 
He added: “Rather than imposing yet more tax on a legitimate UK sector, which directly and indirectly supports over 60,000 jobs and generates over £12bn in tax revenue, the UK Government would be better served by holding an independent review of tobacco tax policy.”
